events.name: Nobel Insights Talk: Not All Those Who Wander Are Lost
events.description:
Nobel Insights Talk: Not All Those Who Wander Are Lost 
Friday, 6 Nov                                                                                                                                                               3pm
Expression Gallery, L4
FREE

Join Sir Harold Walter Kroto as he wanders through both Art and Science to discover connections between the two and the creative potential of a multidisciplinary approach.

Sir Harold Kroto was born in 1939 in Wisbech, United Kingdom during World War II. At Bolton School, Kroto was initially interested in art, geography and gymnastics but he later gravitated towards physics and math with a special interest in chemistry. At the University of Sheffield, he was the art editor of the student magazine, ‘Arrows’ and won several design awards for his book jacket designs.  After earning his PhD in the Spectroscopy of Free Radicals produced by Flash Photolysis, he accepted a postdoctoral position at the Canadian National Research Council in Ottawa and later in Bell Labs in New Jersey. It was a period of great discovery and learning for him where he expanded on his research in spectroscopy and quantum chemistry.  Sir Harold Kroto eventually moved back to Sussex where he was engaged in a research program that he initiated which was designed to detect carbon chains existing in interstellar atmospheres and interstellar gas clouds. This formed the bedrock of the discovery of Carbon-60. Following his 1996 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Kroto has continued conducting fundamental research on the fullerene, examining its basic chemistry and how it has changed the way the scientific world perceives carbon-based materials. Arts and design is also a continual passion for him and he has won numerous accolades with his posters and graphic designs.  Most recently, his design of the Nobel UK Stamp for Chemistry featured at the Royal Academy (London) Summer Exhibition in 2004.

As part of The Nobel Prize Series Singapore 2015 Conference: The Future of Learning, a unique constellation of Nobel Laureates, world-leading experts and key opinion leaders will be speaking at educational and cultural venues across Singapore. The Nobel Museum exhibition "The Nobel Prize – Ideas Changing the World" will be displayed at the ArtScience Museum in Singapore and eminent Sir Harold Kroto will be visiting as part of this bigger programme of Nobel Laureate events.
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: Friday Hacks #103: Science of the Mind & Q&A with the Director of Engineering at Coursera
events.description:
Learn about the science of the mind and bring all your questions from engineering to machine learning to the director of engineering at Coursera.

As usual, pizza will be served before the talks. Hope to see you there!

Topic 1: Science of the mind
The science of the mind has undergone a paradigm shift in the past 25 years. One measure of this shift is the number of scientific papers containing the terms "cognitive neuroscience" or "behavioral economics": in 1990 there were 428 such papers; last year there were more than 20,000. This increase is partly a consequence of an array of new technologies: from single-neuron recording in humans to gene expression mapping to agent-based computational modeling. But the main driver of this increase is a fundamentally new way of viewing human behavior and decision-making. This new approach is mathematical at its core: viewing the brain as an organ whose evolved purpose is to process information and perform computations.

In this talk I'll give a brief account of the concepts and discoveries at the heart this new view of the mind. I'll then talk about some of our most recent research: rethinking education from first principles. Our effort started when we asked the question: "What would education look like if it were invented today, taking into account the latest discoveries in the science of the mind?" Our most recent results involve measuring ways in which students apply focused effort both inside and outside the classroom, the relationship between focused effort and learning, and factors that reliably increase both.

Speaker Profile:
Shaun Martin is co-founder of Applied Cognitive Science, a company that applies cognitive science, behavioral economics and mathematical modeling to the real world. He has a doctorate in mathematics from Oxford University, and previously held lecturing and research positions at MIT and at the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton.

Topic 2: Q&A with director of engineering at Coursera
Jiquan Ngiam will talking about engineering at Coursera. How things got started, how we work in engineering, and the challenges we have. It will be an interactive session, bring all your questions from engineering to machine learning to education.

Speaker Profile:
Jiquan Ngiam was on the founding team of Coursera, an education technology platform that partners with top universities to offer courses online. He currently leads the engineering team, overseeing product, infrastructure, and mobile development. He is invested in creating a future where education is scalable, personalized, and universally accessible. Prior to Coursera, he was pursuing a Ph.D. in Computer Science at Stanford where he co-created online machine learning class that was the genesis of Coursera.

events.name: Nov/2015 - Open Space (Coaching and mentoring)
events.description: Open Space Facilitator: Darren Open Space Theme: Coaching “We are uncovering better ways of developing software by doing it and helping others do it… “ In agile development, we emphasis on the need for continuous improvement. To continually improve, we need to learn from others and also teach others to do things in better ways. The theme for this month is in hope to spark discussions around topics like how can we provide assistance across multiple levels within an organization, or how individual seeks for assistance but not limited to just these. Agenda 7:00pm - Networking and pizza 7:30pm - Topic generation 8:00pm - Breakout sessions 10:00pm - End We welcome contributions of drinks and snacks! =) What is Open Space? Open Space is a highly collaborative and self-organised meeting where topics are generated on the spot and discussed by the participants through breakout sessions. For more information read Open Space Technology.  Getting There Marina Bay Financial Centre Tower 2 is just right above of Downtown station along Downtown Line (DT). Building Access The building requires someone from Barclays to allow people into the lift and to the room. Rohit from Barclays will be at the reception area to help you enter the building. The timings he will make the trip are: 7:00pm, 7:15pm and 7:30pm There is no guarantee of trips after 7:45pm.

events.name: The Cloud and .NET Moment (FREE - DevFest.Asia Edition)
events.description:
This event is part of DevFest.Asia 2015, Southeast Asia's first community organized web developer festival. FREE FOR ALL developers! The next .NET Developers and Azure community meetup will be on Thursday, November 19th, 2015. This is a special edition of .NET developers and Azure community meetup in conjunction with DevFest.Asia 2015. Let's have a Cloud and .NET moment! We have a high caliber speakers from Microsoft, coming down to Singapore, for you all. Do join us for this special Cloud and .NET Moment! Seriously, you might not get this moment again next time. SPEAKER ONE Christian Heilmann: More than 20 years as Web expert, HTML5 and JavaScript expert, spoken at 129 events in 26 countries, a Developer Evangelist - all things for open web, HTML5, writing books, articles, blogs, podcast, Channel 9 (MSDN), YouTube, you name it!   Chris is a Senior Program Manager at Microsoft, working on Microsoft Edge. You want to know what is Microsoft Edge all about, first hand from the person, than you need to join this moment! Ask him! SPEAKER TWO Ryan J. Salva: JS Developer, Apache Cordova Advocate, Visual Studio Program Manager, CrossFitter, SciFi Connoisseur and Whiskey Enthusiast.  Ryan is a Principal Program Manager at Microsoft, working in the Visual Studio Client Tools team where he looks after HTML, CSS and JavaScript development. He comes from a 15 year career in web standards development & advocacy as an entrepreneur, developer and graphic designer. Today, he focuses primarily on mobile app development using web technologies and Apache Cordova. Seriously, if you want to know what is cross-platform or hybrid app, than he is one of the person you should see. Ask him! 

GOODIES There will be a surprise from the community members! I can only tell you this... this thing, you can make call with it, the other one, you can save files on it! Others, you can wear it. That's it! :) Anyone of you can have this, well after you can answer the questions from the speakers. Very limited, so better learn about Microsoft Edge, Apache Cordova, HTML5, Azure and Visual Studio 2015. Also there will be some light refreshment as well (food)!
events.location: NTUC Auditorium, Level 7 NTUC Centre, One Marina Boulevard, Singapore

events.name: ArtScience Late
events.description:
Strangeweather Movement Group with Andy Yang: Spooky Action (at a Distance) II
Thursday 19 November
Performance starts at 8pm
ArtScience Museum, Lobby
FREE


For ArtScience Late, Strangeweather Movement Group revisits a 2013 performance work, Spooky Action (at a Distance), in collaboration with visual artist and musician Andy Yang. In Spooky, Strangeweather considers the theory of quantum entanglement, puts it on the backburner, and creates an off-kilter dance performance of impolite improvisation scores and congruent choreography. Yang intercepts the performance with a resounding set installation and what happens next is anyone’s guess. This rendition of Spooky is performed by Bernice Lee, Faye Lim and Andy Yang. Excerpts of the original performance were featured in filmmaker Karol Jalochowski’s documentary, Reality Lost, which was commissioned by NUS Centre for Quantum
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: WebAudio Hack Day
events.description:
http://2015.devfest.asia/#Sun15 As a part of DevFest.Asia, we're organising a WebAudio HackDay. It's a day long event where we'll work on projects around WebAudio, WebMIDI for fun and profit. And the end we'll gather and share what we've created. We will have a couple of brief talks at the beginning to introduce and inspire us. We're lucky to have Paul Adenot (who maintains the WebAudio implementation in Firefox) and Matt McKegg (who created the WebAudio School project) to help us throughout the day. Schedule (Tentative) 11:00 : Registration 11:15 : Talk 1 (20-30mins) 11:45 : Talk 2 (20-30mins) 12:15 : Introductions + Ideas 13:00 : Lunch 19:00 : Demos 20:00 : Dinner 20:30 : Performance 



Tickets are sold through DevFest.Asia's website. Please get your tickets here http://2015.devfest.asia/#Sat21 


F.A.Q. Q. What is this WebAudio you speak of? A. WebAudio is a (widely supported) W3C standard for generating, analysing and playing audio in the Browser. Checkout the spec here (http://webaudio.github.io/web-audio-api/) 


Q. Where can I learn more about WebAudio A. WebAudio School is a self-help style tutorial for learning WebAudio (http://mmckegg.github.io/web-audio-school/).  We're also hosting a NodeSchool event as a part of DevFest where we'll be around to guide you while you go through NodeSchool (http://2015.devfest.asia/#Sun15) 


Q. Why are there tickets? A. To cover the cost of food and drinks during the day. We're trying to get delicious healthy food for everyone for lunch and dinner. And maaybe some prizes. 


Q. What shall I bring to this HackDay? A. Please bring you down laptop, headphones and anything else you want to use for your project, like MIDI controllers, Arduino, etc.

events.name: Book Club: Architecture of Open Source – Audacity & Web Distributed Systems
events.description: Read The Architecture of Open Source Applications online. This week we'll be covering the chapters on Audacity and Scalable Web Architecture and Distributed Systems. At the end of each week's meetup we will take a vote to select ~two chapters from any of the three AOSA Volumes available. If there's a particular chapter you want us to cover, attend the next meetup and cast your vote!  "If you are a junior developer, and want to learn how your more experienced colleagues think, these books are the place to start. If you are an intermediate or senior developer, and want to see how your peers have solved hard design problems, these books can help you too." How Book Club Works1. Read the chapter before you come to the meetup.2. Find something in the chapter you found interesting and maybe research it a little more.3. At the meetup, we go around the room and each person gets a chance to tell the group about the thing they found interesting.4. Group discussion and banter ensues! Book club is held at Tim & Wei's residence: 244A Tanjong Katong RdSingapore  437032Singapore Doors open at 6:30, meetup starts at 7. Bring snacks! Feel free to ask questions in the SingaporeJS gitter room: https://gitter.im/SingaporeJS/discussions
events.location: Tim & Wei's Residence, 244A Tanjong Katong Road, Singapore

events.name: dplyr tricks
events.description: Hi everyone, I would like to suggest a dplyr discussion session. My vision is that the expert users in our group could come forward and share some tips and tricks that they have figured out after using dplyr for some time. It would be sort of an open-mic session. As such, it will not be a tutorial on dplyr; but a session to find out and share solutions with others.  If you have some expertise, please get in touch with me to let me what you would be interested to share, and I can arrange a schedule. If each person just talks for 5-10 minutes with a short example, it would be wonderful. For my part, I propose to talk about the following: 1. using dplyr verbs within other functions. (use of the standard evaluation versions of filter, select, etc.) 2. window functions with dplyr. I haven't fixed a date yet, but targeting Nov 18th if possible.

Hackware is a monthly meetup for hardware developers and enthusiasts to share hacks and developments in the hardware scene, promote hardware development and to build a community of hardware developers. 

Our talks typically include side projects by speakers on electronics, embedded system, radio communications, internet of things, radio frequency and much more! Come and just drop by for all our open and free meetups, make friends with fellow enthusiasts or beginners and feel free to sign up for a talk slot on whatever you are working on.

We collaborate with Science Bites!, a science communication initiative in Science Centre Singapore this November to bring you the wonders of astronomy and science in SCS's Digital Planetarium!

events.name: Security In The World Of CI-CD
events.description: Continuous Delivery (CD) is a set of practices and principles in software engineering aimed at, building, testing, and releasing software, faster and more frequently. These principles help reduce the cost, time and risk of delivering changes, and ultimately value, to customers by allowing for more incremental changes to applications in production. Continuous integration (CI) is the practice, in software engineering, of merging all developer working copies to a shared mainline several times a day. In the same vein, the practice of continuous delivery further extends CI by making sure the software checked in on the mainline is always in a state that can be deployed to users and makes the actual deployment process very rapid. So, in this rapid and fast world of CI-CD, focusing on highly scalable & highly portable software landscape, which offers high usage oriented web apps, the security landscape has really reached to cutting edge point. This talk, will focus on how to posturize security with this fast pace world, covering most of all security verticals. Speaker:Aniket Kulkarni, carries decade+ of software security experience flowing from QA, Development & Architecture.Currently he works as Software Security Architect (Bigdata\Cloud\Mobile\Web), in Autodesk Singapore R&D, one of world class design software developing companies across the globe. For more information about Aniket, kindly get connected with him on linkedin: https://sg.linkedin.com/pub/aniket-kulkarni/10/653/202 , and he will be happy to interact with you for various security related discussions.
events.location: Akamai Singapore office, 1 Raffles Place, #16-61, One Raffles Place Tower 2, Singapore 048616

events.name: Productionizing data science at scale (Strata x Hadoop SG Community Event)
events.description: Coming December, we are proud to close the year with our biggest meetup yet - at Strata x Hadoop SG! Registration will open on 8th November, 1230pm. Free event, open to all (no need for strata x hadoop tickets). For folks who wish to attend the full Strata x Hadoop conference, feel free to use our community's discount code UGDSSG for a 20% discount on the tickets. List of panelist & speakers • Albert Bifet (Institut Mines-Télécom) (panel) • Shirshanka Das (Linkedin) (panel) • Wes McKinney (Cloudera) (panel) • Jennifer Marsman (Microsoft) (panel) • Bin Fan (Tachyon Nexus) (tech startup lightning talk) • Fangjin Yang (Imply) (tech startup lightning talk) Agenda • 530pm-6pm: Networking session • 6pm-6.15pm: Introduction to Memory-centric Distributed Storage System Tachyon and Its Use Case by Bin Fan. • 6.15pm-6.30pm: Introduction to Druid by Fangjin Yang  • 6.30pm-6.45pm: tech startup lightning talk 3 (speaker confirming travel schedule) • 6.45pm - 8pm: Panel discussion - Productionizing data science at scale with Albert Bifet, Shirshanka Das, Wes McKinney and Jennifer Marsman. • 8pm - 830pm: Networking session Profile of speakers: Panelist • Albert Bifet is a big data scientist with 10+ years of international experience in research and in leading new open source software projects for business analytics, data mining, and machine learning (Institut Mines-Télécom, Huawei, Yahoo, University of Waikato, UPC). He obtained a Ph.D. from UPC-BarcelonaTech. Albert has worked in Hong Kong, New Zealand, and Europe. At Yahoo Labs, he co-founded Apache SAMOA (Scalable Advanced Massive Online Analysis) in 2013. Apache SAMOAis a distributed streaming machine learning (ML) framework that contains a programing abstraction for distributed streaming ML algorithms. At the WEKA Machine Learning group, he has co-led MOA (Massive Online Analysis) since 2008.  • Shirshanka Das is the architect for LinkedIn’s Data Analytics Infrastructure team. He was among the original authors of a variety of open and closed source projects built at LinkedIn, including Databus, Espresso, and Apache Helix. His current focus at LinkedIn includes all things Hadoop, high-performance distributed OLAP engines, large-scale data ingestion, transformation and movement, and data lineage and discovery. • Wes McKinney is a software engineer at Cloudera and lead developer of Ibis. He is the creator of Python’s pandas library and is the author of Python for Data Analysis. Previously, Wes was the founder and CEO of DataPad. •  Jennifer Marsman is a principal developer evangelist in Microsoft’s Developer and Platform Evangelism group, where she educates developers on Microsoft’s new technologies. In this role, Jennifer is a frequent speaker at software development conferences across the United States. In 2009, Jennifer was chosen as “Techie whose innovation will have the biggest impact” by X-OLOGY for her work with GiveCamps, a weekend-long event where developers code for charity. Prior to becoming a developer evangelist, Jennifer was a software developer in Microsoft’s Natural Interactive Services division. In this role, she earned two patents for her work in search and data mining algorithms. Tech Startup Lightning Talks: Bin Fan is a software engineer at Tachyon Nexus. He is one of the top committers in the open source community of Tachyon project. Prior to Tachyon Nexus, he worked in Google to build the core storage infrastructure and won Google’s Technical Infrastructure award. Bin got his PhD in computer science from Carnegie Mellon University. Talk details: Introduction to Memory-centric Distributed Storage System Tachyon and Its Use Case Memory is the key to fast Big Data processing. This has been realized by many, and frameworks such as Spark and Shark already leverage memory performance. As data sets continue to grow, storage is increasingly becoming a critical bottleneck in many workloads. To address this need, we have developed Tachyon, a memory centric fault-tolerant distributed file system, which enables reliable file sharing at memory-speed across cluster frameworks, such as Spark and MapReduce. Tachyon caches working set files in memory, and enables different jobs/queries and frameworks to access cached files at memory speed. Tachyon as an open-source system has more than 160 contributors from over 50 institutions, including IBM, Yahoo, Intel, Redhat, Baidu, and Tachyon Nexus. In the presentation, we will also explore several potential industry use cases enabled by the new features.  Fangjin Yang is a co-author of the open source Druid project and a co-founder of Imply, a data analytics startup based in San Francisco. Previously, he held senior engineering positions at Metamarkets and Cisco Systems. Fangjin holds a BASc in Electrical Engineering and a MASc in Computer Engineering from the University of Waterloo, Canada.
events.location: Suntec Singapore Convention & Exhibition Centre Room 321 - 322 (Level 3), 1 Raffles Boulevard, Suntec City, Singapore 03959, Level 3

events.name: Why ignoring digital perf can cost digital agencies & marketers a lot of money?
events.description: Today’s websites are no longer solely marketing channels, they are critical production factors. If a website fails to deliver a satisfactory customer experience the entire value delivery chain is broken, and a company will not generate revenue regardless of product quality or value proposition.Mastering digital performance is one of the leading challenges of the web economy, and requires a joint effort between IT and the lines of business. It means measuring and managing the end-to-end transaction delivery and translating it into actionable information. Ultimately user experience is your best success metric. If you’re not proactively addressing digital performance issues, users are more likely to take their complaints to their social streams than to call-in and report it. Join our digital performance meetup where, Dave Anderson, Marketing Director, Dynatrace APAC discusses how Digital Performance analytic can optimise the users experience of your website or applications and improve conversions.
events.location: Lime house, 2 Jiak Chuan road 089260, Singapore

events.name: Sunday Showcase
events.description:
Sunday Showcase allows visitors unique access to cutting edge projects being undertaken by different tertiary institutions across Singapore. The series invites the creators and their work into ArtScience Museum on a Sunday each month. The creators are on hand throughout the afternoon to talk with visitors about their inventions, their creative process, and to facilitate visitors' interaction with the projects. There is something for everyone in this hands-on, accessible showcase series.

Innovati50n reconstructed @ ArtScience museum
An Interlude of Science meets Art by A*STAR & NAFA
(Workshops and ‘pop up’ talks throughout the day)
Saturday and Sunday, 5 & 6 December
10am - 7pm
ArtScience Museum, Level 4
FREE


The Agency of Science, Technology and Research (A*STAR) & the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts (NAFA) have created 17 science-inspired exhibits using
an array of artistic techniques such as fine art, digital art, photography, sculpture and others. Meet the scientists and artists behind this creative showcase of Singapore’s scientific innovations and get hands-on with our unique Science-Art workshops and demos.
events.location: ArtScience Museum

events.name: Micro Hack Mondays
events.description: A space to meet like-minded people in the media & from the developer beat every first Monday of the month over food & drinks. Perfect for anyone who has a story or an idea that could be told interactively but doesn't know where or how to get started. Or, for anyone who has a new code or library to try out but doesn't have a story angle yet. More information to come - we'll send out announcements soon.
events.location: ST Innovation Lab - SPH, 1000 Toa Payoh North, Singapore

events.name: EML30 Music Festival
events.description:
In celebration of NUS Electronic Music Lab's 30th anniversary, we are holding the EML30 Music Festival on the 12th December at Lepark Singapore from 12pm to 6pm.

EML30 Music Festival will play host to 2, hour-long music forums to discuss the eco-system of electronic music in Singapore beyond 2015, amongst varsity institutional groups and industry leaders respectively.

In addition, there will be 4 hours of original electronic music by our artists, such as Ocean's Children, Kids With Laptops, Mitch Advent, nanowander, Brannlum and many more throughout the afternoon, spanning a multitude of genres accompanied by stunning visuals.

Food and drinks can be purchased at Lepark, so be sure to enjoy the delicious food and tasteful craft beers while you catch the show.

TICKET PRICES:

EML Starter Pack (Whilst Stocks Last) - FREE
Starter Pack to receive a EML Wristband and Sticker (Includes RSVP)

EML Silver Pack - $29.95
You will receive the following items: Exclusive EML30 T-Shirt (Pre-Order Only) and EML Starter Pack (Wristband + Stickers)

EML Gold Pack - $111.95
Exclusive Limited Edition EML30 T-Shirt (Pre-Order Only), EML T-Shirt, EML Drawstring Bag, EML Starter Pack, EML Albums and Cassette Tapes
events.location: Lepark

events.name: Hackware v1.4
events.description: Hackware is a monthly meetup for hardware developers and enthusiasts to share hacks and developments in the hardware scene, promote hardware development and to build a community of hardware developers. Our talks typically include side projects by speakers on electronics, embedded system, radio communications, internet of things, radio frequency and much more! Come and just drop by for all our open and free meetups, make friends with fellow enthusiasts or beginners and feel free to sign up for a talk slot on whatever you are working on. Agenda & Talks for this meetup: 1. (20min) Design for Manufacturing - Daniël J Ellis2. (10min) Tictactoe playing robotic arm using OpenCV - Juan Miguel Jimeno3. (10min) IoT hardware with Meteor Javascript - Rick Behl 4. Announcements by anyone on:- Hiring positions- Available for hire- Other upcoming hardware-related events locally or anywhere else 5. Socialize and Network with other Hackware members Talks : ~20minsLightning Talks : ~5minsAnnouncements: ~1min Venue sponsors: Thank you IDA Singapore, Sandcrawler ♥
events.location: IDA @ Sandcrawler, 1 Fusionopolis View, #08-02 Sandcrawler, 138577, Singapore
